user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of get_rq_nc:
```c
static enum MHD_GetRqNCResult
get_rq_nc (const struct MHD_RqDAuth *params,
           uint32_t *nc)
{
  const struct MHD_RqDAuthParam *const nc_param =
    &params->nc;
  char unq[16];
  const char *val;
  size_t val_len;
  size_t res;
  uint64_t nc_val;

  if (NULL == nc_param->value.str)
    return MHD_GET_RQ_NC_NONE;

  if (0 == nc_param->value.len)
    return MHD_GET_RQ_NC_BROKEN;

  if (! nc_param->quoted)
  {
    val = nc_param->value.str;
    val_len = nc_param->value.len;
  }
  else
  {
    /* Actually no backslashes must be used in 'nc' */
    if (sizeof(unq) < params->nc.value.len)
      return MHD_GET_RQ_NC_TOO_LONG;
    val_len = MHD_str_unquote (nc_param->value.str, nc_param->value.len, unq);
    if (0 == val_len)
      return MHD_GET_RQ_NC_BROKEN;
    val = unq;
  }

  res = MHD_strx_to_uint64_n_ (val, val_len, &nc_val);
  if (0 == res)
  {
    const char f = val[0];
    if ( (('9' >= f) && ('0' <= f)) ||
         (('F' >= f) && ('A' <= f)) ||
         (('a' <= f) && ('f' >= f)) )
      return MHD_GET_RQ_NC_TOO_LARGE;
    else
      return MHD_GET_RQ_NC_BROKEN;
  }
  if (val_len != res)
    return MHD_GET_RQ_NC_BROKEN;
  if (UINT32_MAX < nc_val)
    return MHD_GET_RQ_NC_TOO_LARGE;
  *nc = (uint32_t) nc_val;
  return MHD_GET_RQ_NC_VALID;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No direct use of memcmp is present in the shown function. All other string handling in this fragment is length-aware (uses explicit length fields like nc_param->value.len and val_len) or single-character checks (e.g. using val[0] stored in 'f' and range comparisons). The local buffer 'unq' is used together with an explicit returned length. There are no occurrences of memcmp or any obvious comparisons of null-terminated strings performed with memcmp in the rest of the code fragment, so those statements do not require investigation for Rule 21.14. The only places in this fragment that could hide a memcmp usage are the external/helper function calls listed in suspicious_frags; all other lines are safe with respect to MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14.
